note.body: Small edit: using proper remote branches.

target_title: icons: add navigation icons, update style.

note.body:
@cmyk.student Do you know that you can push to a MR branch?

Here is how you'd do it:

1. Fetch the branch: `git fetch git@ssh.gitlab.gnome.org:rangelovd/gimp-data.git add-missing-navigation-icons`
2. Then checkout the FETCH_HEAD: `git checkout FETCH_HEAD`
3. Then make your changes and create your new commit.
4. Finally push to the contributor's branch: `git push -u git@ssh.gitlab.gnome.org:rangelovd/gimp-data.git HEAD:add-missing-navigation-icons`

Just so you know. When contributors create a MR, Gitlab gives us the temporary right to push to the branch from which the MR was made. :-)

Then no need to wait for the contributor to make change when we want something done quickly. ;-)

Anyway if you don't have the time, no prob. I can try to do it a bit later.

note.body:
@rangelovd Hey! Okay, at the bottom of `legacy_tools_scalable` you would add these lines:

```
  '../Default/scalable/view-shrink-wrap-symbolic.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/view-shrink-wrap.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/view-zoom-fill-symbolic.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/view-zoom-fill.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/zoom-fit-best.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/zoom-in.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/zoom-original.svg',
  '../Default/scalable/zoom-out.svg',
```

That copies the files into the Legacy scalable folder. To also add them to Default, you'd go to `\icons\icon-lists\scalable.list` and add these lines right after `view-refresh`:

```
view-shrink-wrap
view-zoom-fill
window-new
zoom-fit-best
zoom-in
zoom-original
zoom-out
```

You can also add them in the same spot to `bitmap_16.list` if you like.

@rangelovd Hey! Sure thing. You would add four entries inside here:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp-data/-/blob/main/icons/Legacy/meson.build#L368

```
'scalable/gimp-toggle-on.svg',
'scalable/gimp-toggle-on-symbolic.svg',
'scalable/gimp-toggle-off.svg',
'scalable/gimp-toggle-off-symbolic.svg',
```

Let me know if you want me to add that, or if you're comfortable doing it yourself.
Needs meson magic to work. @cmyk.student could you please help me with that?

My theory is that it's caused by Windows default font which we are using now: Segoe UI 9pt (before we were using Microsoft Sans 8pt from Windows XP). Please, let's discuss on the proper issue: gimp#11677

> I designed the Welcome page to have the image covering the whole page

@Jehan Yeah, that was a long time in the past. 2.8 installer looks very great. Not true, however, for 2.99. Your intention is lost since many years. Just download 2.99.16 installer and see the borders:

![image](/uploads/b16d73c0350169a1bfb1f8363d4d139f/image.png){width=437 height=362}

> Since the installer was redesigned to be more squarish

No. I will repeat what I said on IRC that the installer dimensions were **never** touched by me to it look "square". The final size depends on the language, which depends on the font, which depends on the scaling, which depends on the resolution etc. All of this is described in gimp#11677 but just to keep clear as day, this is the same 2.99.16 installer in two different languages:

| English | Georgian |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_140923](/uploads/cbd75e4c7f756aae26a3679587d0035c/Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_140923.png) | ![Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_141021](/uploads/9c7bba6a49491300963162b8ac9a9e1b/Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_141021.png) |

The same goes for 2.10:

| English | Georgian |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_141326](/uploads/4a8bb2770a9be204852eeeec2164b915/Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_141326.png) | ![Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_141340](/uploads/dd0347ce5d09ed18c0c6c23532df2be4/Captura_de_tela_2024-12-20_141340.png) |

So, nothing new under the sun. I think that changing the dimensions of the .jpegs wouldn't fix the issue for all languages.

> That is how @jernejs designed this welcome page, probably due to Inno limitations.

I designed the Welcome page to have the image covering the whole page, with no borders and the buttons covering the image (and due to the way the Setup form is built, I had to use two image objects). Since the installer was redesigned to be more squarish, it would IMHO make sense to change the images to the new aspect ratio.

Ok implemented with commit cd59b23be0aa686493d6083d3ec678387e7eda78 per last comments. If anyone has counter-suggestions, especially you @sevenixvii, please feel free to reopen the discussion.

The ugly squishing will still happen (cf. gimp#11677) so if anyone has a solution for this, feel free. At least it's only in the installer, not in GIMP (either splash or welcome dialog) itself!

```
commit cd59b23be0aa686493d6083d3ec678387e7eda78 (HEAD -> main, origin/main, origin/HEAD)
Author: Jehan <jehan@girinstud.io>
Date:   Fri Dec 20 01:45:34 2024 +0100

    Issue #5: use the image itself with blur and noise as its own background.

 images/splash2installer.py | 39 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++--------
 1 file changed, 31 insertions(+), 8 deletions(-)
```

note.body: I give it 10.5 out of 10.5 :P
@sevenixvii Since your splash is the next target, what do you think of the render above in my last comment?
Green light for scripting

This is a mockup with blur at 27.5 (how specific it is! 😁), and a tiny bit of HSV noise. How does it look?

![new-mockup-blur-27-5-noise](/uploads/0c4a9a1712cba47cb686cec99f2f4a75/new-mockup-blur-27-5-noise.jpg)

And here is the RC1 version, using the exact same blur and noise values (since the idea will be to automatize):

![new-mockup-rc1-blur-27-5-noise](/uploads/4d690464db08023eb4aeef066e7e3a50/new-mockup-rc1-blur-27-5-noise.jpg)

And for even more generic view, here is the 2.10 splash processed the same:

![new-mockup-210-blur-27-5-noise](/uploads/eaf29214a84c0a2dde6b92316c77fb40/new-mockup-210-blur-27-5-noise.jpg)
Maybe a blur of 27,5 would please everyone.

I don't like blur only, and how low intense it is. Looks Windows 7/"keygenish" to me unlike a lot of blur w/ noise, that also aligns with recent Fluent design direction. 

Though it's better than black anyway. So I won't be against it. Feel free to commit changes :smile:

@rangelovd I must be honest that I prefer @Jehan design, specially the first screenshot.

@Jehan I can't talk about the noise because of the image compression

> why were the various splashes squished in all the mockups above?

@Jehan That is how @jernejs designed this welcome page, probably due to Inno limitations. See: GNOME/gimp#11677

Both of these looks nice. My main fear with this was that the buttons themselves would become less distinct but it seems to work out quite well, at least in this example.

I think the one using Gaussian blur 15 looks better of the two as it leaves some structure of the original image, making it look more of an extension.
Yeah this was discussed on IRC indeed. Scripting such thing is not hard at all. We just have to find the generic image editing rules which we want to apply.

Are the last mockups also blurs? It looks like they are so blurred that it's barely a single color. If that's what we want, then computing some kind of average-like color can be done by scaling the splash to 1×1 and using the unique pixel's color.

This being said, I did like a bit the blur effect. For instance, this is simply the new splash with a gaussian blur 15:

![new-mockup-blur-15](/uploads/e3058542ca6776b86406dfbb032fab13/new-mockup-blur-15.jpg)

Now if we really want it stronger, here is with a blur 40:

![new-mockup-blur-40](/uploads/970947ac71f62e1b1113a0ce46ae0bc5/new-mockup-blur-40.jpg)

I am unsure if the added noise + light which makes the whole thing uniform-looking (apart from noise, I mean color-wise). I do like that we can still see some gradient-like colors and you understand it comes from the image.

By the way, why were the various splashes squished in all the mockups above?

That is the darkened blur render, as we discussed on IRC.

Could you send the lightened render with .xcf (so I can instruct @Jehan on what he will script)?
@lillolollo We do not plan to manually make the blurred background (I think the descriptiom not said this). This will be done in Python enhancing the existing slpash2installer.py script.

I think @brunolopesdsilv is right the black background it is not very pleasant, but @Jehan worked hard to automate the process so changing the background for every splash screen it is not a good idea. 
I see the @rangelovd mockup, a solution could be apply a heavy blur to image, pick a random pixel color and use it as back ground. 
I think this could be the most simple solution without over engineered code.

push_data.commit_title: icons/Legacy: Update meson.build and remove PNGs

note.body:
Answered on IRC. For the record:

```
14:41 < rangelovd> Jehan:I changed icons canvas to 24x24 from whatever was before
14:42 < rangelovd> Jehan: I've used penpot to save some of the icons. Hence the different tags I suppose
[…]
14:45 < Jehan> rangelovd: when you change canvas size, do you mean that the icon is also scaled? Or really only the canvas?
14:45 < Jehan> (therefore icon would be smaller and some space added on the side)
14:46 < rangelovd> Jehan: 22x22-> 24x24 only canvas. 16x16->24x24 or 48x48->24x24 icon too
```

So first of all, I squashed all your commits into one + the one from @cmyk.student in my local copy. I'm hesitated to keep the ones you said you replace (I think it was "desaturate"?) in a separate commit, but since it's still based on the original design, let's all keep as one commit.

> I've added Paint Select from Default theme.
> […]
>> gimp-tool-mypaint-brush
>
> I took this icon from Default theme. It is unchanged.

These are indeed exact copies, as shown by diff. You added them by copying the file. Let's not do that. One of the point of a separate repository was to have smaller data (allowing people to make shallow copies of a data repo), let's not duplicate everything. Even more true for organization purpose. When some data is just a copy of another, let's make it clear by how we organize our data.

So instead, I edited @cmyk.student's commit to add both these files from Default through meson, and removed the copies by editing your commit.

> I picked the icon that was present in Legacy/scalable, scaled it down to 24x24, then make slight adjustments so it would render sharper on small sizes (16,24)

Hmm… is it just me if I find the new icon less sharp in fact?

Left is the new icon, right is the original one:

![Screenshot_from_2024-10-27_14-09-46](/uploads/5556009a8554b7aa79bb04664bd08b18/Screenshot_from_2024-10-27_14-09-46.png)

The new one nearly feels blurry to me, even more when comparing side by side.

> Sure. gimp-tool-paintbrush, gimp-tool-bucket-fill are from Default theme, unchanged.

But you tweaked them, right? A diff shows they are quite different and when displaying them and zooming, we can see differences.

Also which tool did you use to edit SVG? These SVG don't like edited by Inkscape (none of the usual Inkscape tags + the indentation is all broken).

@Jehan this is because when I first saw this sharp bright outline, it felt like the icon was created for light theme(opaque white background to be precise), and then magic wand was created to remove white, and then it was removed with this not-very-nice-looking line. Most of the icons I've drawn by eye, without looking in the .XCF. Only when I looked at .XCF, I realised that this light is deliberate. I made a note for myself to explore this further:

![image](/uploads/7fbed1d49a501af395f407001eaf7945/image.png)

Most likely, what will happen is I introduce the encompassing line but it will be much more transparent, thin and smooth. I felt that this is not something that should block the merge. You may disagree, and my intention by saying that is: I acknowledge the problem and I'm commited to fixing it. This is exactly why in description of this merge request there is a notice:  `In my opinion it is an improvement. If you find some change you're not in fond with we can discuss and change this!`

The good thing is, the more I make these icons, the faster I am in making them. They are so nuanced, they require a specific conclusion at times. And as I come to the conclusions, it becomes a problem of the past and I just reuse and apply the logic of what I need to do. So later, in case of encompassing line I wouldn't need to guess.

> most of the icons are as-close-as-possible vector versions of the existing Legacy icons. 

Yes.

> "_Pencil, color-picker and handle-transform are from Inkscape Tango icon theme_" -\> still the case? Are the files untouched?

Yes, the files are untouched. That being said, I'd like to experiment with replacing color-picker in the future and proposing that to Inkscape.

> did you add any of the missing tool icons? ~~If so, which ones and which license you want to use for them?~~

I didn't create any icons that were previously missing in Legacy. cmyk.student added 3d-transform from Default theme, I've added Paint Select from Default theme.

> gimp-gegl: unchanged.

Correct.

> gimp-tool-measure: you say you adjusted it, what does it mean exactly?

I picked the icon that was present in Legacy/scalable, scaled it down to 24x24, then make slight adjustments so it would render sharper on small sizes (16,24) while not being too simple on huge sizes (i made two nodes smoother, increased spacing, increased outline). Both my initial icon and the one present in GIMP already were unsuitable, imo. I found balance.

> gimp-tool-desaturate

I've created a lot of icons before finding out they exist elsewhere (be it Default, Legacy/scalable or Inkscape). When I relised that, I compared existing icons with mine side by side. some icons, like Inkscape pencil were better then pencil drawn by me. With gimp-tool-desaturate, it's the opposite. I feel that my icon looks closer to the raster icon present in Legacy theme. Hence, I removed it and placed mine.

> gimp-tool-mypaint-brush

I took this icon from Default theme. It is unchanged.

> gimp-tool-cage: same, did you do something?

I took this icon from Default theme. Then, I applied changes to it. Please take my word - it's not simple for me to reacll in detail what exactly was changed. Here's the icon side by side.

![image](/uploads/a57ffd9a2baf5673eec1cbc0fb317287/image.png)

> "_A few icons have visible style change (thinking of gimp-tool-ellipse-select in particular, tweaked colors, shadows and corner radius)._: which list of icons exactly, apart from ellipse select?

Now that I'm thinking of it, after my late tweaks, the changes are not that drastic. I can't think of clear examples and that's a good thing, means I recreated them very well.

> Something else to know?

Sure. gimp-tool-paintbrush, gimp-tool-bucket-fill are from Default theme, unchanged.

gimp-tool-smudge is from default theme. There is one vector object removed. It's basically unnoticable. Maybe even unnecessary.

gimp-tool-handle-transform is from default theme, only changed canvas to 24x24

gimp-tool-text is from default theme, tweaked a little.

![image](/uploads/8e47091afa4d970d1e0b5ae2a7433f31/image.png)

note.body:
Comparing icons side by side, I notice some have lost the encompassing line and that makes them harder to see in the dark theme. This is mostly visible on the airbrush tool:

![Screenshot_from_2024-10-26_17-15-45](/uploads/c42837448b6a998ca4bde7ecb6e93c2f/Screenshot_from_2024-10-26_17-15-45.png)

Top is png Legacy, bottom is the new SVG version. As you can see, the SVG version is harder to distinguish because colors are very alike with the dark theme. The solution is that for color icons, every piece of color next to the background must **always** have a different color border, unless it's really not flat coloring (color changing make this less a problem). Here there is in flat some gradient, but maybe because it is so perpendicular to the stick, or maybe because the icon is too small, it doesn't make enough of a color distinction.

P.S.: I'm not asking you to fix this now, because I'm eager to just merge this and go on with my next task 😛. But this is a note for further improvements.
Apart from these few questions, I just tested and it looks nice! :-)

@rangelovd So to summarize:

* most of the icons are as-close-as-possible vector versions of the existing Legacy icons.
* "*Pencil, color-picker and handle-transform are from Inkscape Tango icon theme*" -> still the case? Are the files untouched?
* did you add any of the missing tool icons? If so, which ones and which license you want to use for them?
* Some icons were already existing as SVG. If not mistaken, this is:
  - gimp-gegl: unchanged.
  - gimp-tool-measure: you say you adjusted it, what does it mean exactly?
  - gimp-tool-desaturate: you say you replaced it, you mean it's a completely new design?
  - gimp-tool-mypaint-brush: you don't say, did you do something about it?
  - gimp-tool-cage: same, did you do something?
* "*A few icons have visible style change (thinking of gimp-tool-ellipse-select in particular, tweaked colors, shadows and corner radius).*: which list of icons exactly, apart from ellipse select?
* Something else to know?

note.body: Haven't tested myself, but @cmyk.student did and that should be fine (otherwise it means gimp#8855 fix is not right and we still have a bug to fix). Let's merge.

GEGL is fine. Desaturation is replaced in favour of the icon that more closely represents the raster and doesn't have the odd "white shadow". Measure tool is adjusted for better scaling.

The goal of this merge request was to move from raster to vector. I hope for stylistic changes after 3.0(they are more of a wish-list rather then truly impacting issues). Ready for review, testing and feedback @Jehan, @cmyk.student and anybody else preferring Legacy theme =)
